parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Across multiple European countries, reducing or avoiding inversion tillage has been reported to increase earthworm biomass and, in some cases, species richness.
[Statement 2]: Reducing or avoiding inversion tillage has been reported to raise the abundance of some invertebrates.
[Statement 3]: Reducing or avoiding inversion tillage can increase the numbers of some weeds and/or weed species.
[Statement 4]: Reducing or avoiding inversion tillage can benefit some birds, leading to higher Eurasian skylark nest density, earlier laying, and shorter foraging distances.
[Statement 5]: Non-inversion or conservation tillage can result in a greater late-winter abundance of skylarks, seed-eating songbirds, and gamebirds.
[Statement 6]: A review reported more invertebrate bird-food resources are available under no-till farming.
[Statement 7]: Reduced soil loss and runoff have been reported as benefits of reduced tillage in several trials that included European sites, though results were mixed overall.
[Statement 8]: Studies including Europe have found higher soil organic carbon under no-till or reduced tillage.
[Statement 9]: One randomized, replicated trial in Spain found that reduced tillage did not lead to higher soil organic carbon.
[Statement 10]: Reduced tillage has been reported to maintain or increase soil organic matter.
[Statement 11]: Reduced tillage has been reported to improve soil structure.
[Statement 12]: In some studies, reduced tillage has resulted in higher nutrient retention.
[Statement 13]: Reported drawbacks of reducing tillage include cases of negative, no, or inconsistent effects on some invertebrates, weeds, mammals, and some bird species.
[Statement 14]: One study noted that bird preferences for conservation-tillage fields declined over time.
[Statement 15]: Reducing tillage has shown mixed long-term effects on earthworms.
[Statement 16]: Weed responses to reduced tillage also varied by crop type.
[Statement 17]: Soil physical responses to reduced tillage were mixed.
[Statement 18]: Some replicated trials, including those in Europe, found higher compaction under reduced tillage.
[Statement 19]: Trials from Europe and India found that conventional ploughing and sub-soiling resulted in greater soil cracking reduction, higher infiltration, and higher soil water content than reduced tillage.
[Statement 20]: No-till practices increased soil loss where crop cover was absent.
[Statement 21]: A randomized, replicated study from Portugal reported no effect of tillage treatment on yield.

key: _gpt-5__What are the documented benefits and potential drawbacks of reducing tillage on European farmland?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Topsoil removal is a technique for restoring or creating species-rich wet meadows.
[Statement 2]: The introduction of target plant species is a technique for restoring or creating species-rich wet meadows.
[Statement 3]: Raising water levels is a technique for restoring or creating species-rich wet meadows.
[Statement 4]: Grazing is a technique for restoring or creating species-rich wet meadows.
[Statement 5]: Mowing is a technique for restoring or creating species-rich wet meadows.
[Statement 6]: Combinations of topsoil removal with species introductions can be used for restoring or creating species-rich wet meadows.
[Statement 7]: Livestock exclusion is a technique for restoring or creating species-rich wet meadows.
[Statement 8]: Grazing is a grassland restoration technique used to build species-rich swards.
[Statement 9]: Introducing plant species is a grassland restoration technique used to build species-rich swards.
[Statement 10]: Hay spreading is a grassland restoration technique used to build species-rich swards.
[Statement 11]: Mowing is a grassland restoration technique used to build species-rich swards.
[Statement 12]: Hydrological management includes raising water levels in ditches or grassland to promote wetland plant assemblages typical of wet grassland.
[Statement 13]: Management within wet meadows includes annual autumn mowing or light grazing with cattle or horses.
[Statement 14]: Management within wet meadows includes the removal of trees and shrubs encroaching on wet meadows.
[Statement 15]: Burning is sometimes used as a management method on fen meadows.

key: _gpt-5__In European agricultural landscapes, what management techniques are available to restore or create species-rich wet meadows?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Many comparative studies found higher use or benefits for wildlife on set-aside land than on cropped fields.
[Statement 2]: A UK systematic review showed significantly higher farmland bird densities on set-aside land in both winter and summer.
[Statement 3]: Some studies found that set-aside land had mixed, no, or adverse effects on wildlife.
[Statement 4]: Skylark nesting success was found to be higher on set-aside land in two UK studies but lower in one.
[Statement 5]: Some animal species occur at higher densities or use set-aside land more than other habitats, while some occur at lower densities.
[Statement 6]: Species richness was often higher on set-aside land than on land with crops.
[Statement 7]: Waders and skylarks had higher productivity on set-aside land in three of four studies.
[Statement 8]: One study found lower skylark productivity on set-aside land.
[Statement 9]: Naturally regenerated set-aside land tended to hold more birds and species than sown set-aside land.
[Statement 10]: Evidence on the benefits of rotational versus non-rotational set-aside was mixed.
[Statement 11]: Set-aside land did not increase small mammal or brown hare numbers relative to cropland or other non-crop habitats.
[Statement 12]: Wood mice used uncut set-aside land more after harvest.
[Statement 13]: Several studies found higher species richness and, in some cases, higher abundance of butterflies and moths on sown or naturally regenerating set-aside versus cereal fields.
[Statement 14]: The benefits for butterflies and moths on set-aside land were especially apparent when less competitive grasses were present.
[Statement 15]: Other studies found the richness or abundance of butterflies and moths on set-aside land was similar to that on arable, pasture, or uncultivated habitats.
[Statement 16]: Syntheses of multiple replicated studies found no clear benefits to birds from converting arable land to permanent grassland.
[Statement 17]: One controlled before-and-after UK study reported significant declines in the grey partridge population after arable land was reverted to grassland.
[Statement 18]: Studies show that restored grasslands can develop butterfly and moth communities increasingly similar to high-quality grasslands over the first decade.
[Statement 19]: The species richness of butterflies and moths was often higher on restored grasslands than on conventional grassland or cultivated farms.
[Statement 20]: The abundance of butterflies and moths on restored grasslands was sometimes higher than on conventional grassland or crop fields.
[Statement 21]: The abundance of butterflies and moths on restored grasslands did not always increase with time since restoration.
[Statement 22]: Sowing restored grasslands with diverse mixes or with forbs/perennial mixes often increased butterfly and moth richness or abundance compared with grass-only mixes.
[Statement 23]: Following schemes that included grassland reversion, some butterfly and moth taxa increased while others decreased.

key: _gpt-5__To mitigate the impacts of intensive arable farming, what are the effects of taking land out of production, either as set-aside or by converting it to grassland?
_gpt-5__What are some alternatives to direct predator control for improving the breeding success of ground-nesting birds on farmland?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Protecting individual nests using exclosures increased average daily nest survival for common redshank and northern lapwing.
[Statement 2]: The use of exclosures raised hatching rates for southern dunlin.
[Statement 3]: One study noted higher predation of adult redshank at protected nests.
[Statement 4]: The creation of uncropped, cultivated margins or plots, including ‘lapwing plots’, has been associated with increased northern lapwing hatching success.
[Statement 5]: Uncropped, cultivated margins or plots have been associated with improved Eurasian skylark nesting success.
[Statement 6]: Northern lapwing, Eurasian skylark, grey partridge and yellow wagtail have been found breeding in uncropped, cultivated plots.

[Statement 1]: Across multiple studies and reviews, overwinter stubbles were associated with benefits for some farmland birds.
[Statement 2]: Overwinter stubbles were associated with higher winter densities of farmland birds.
[Statement 3]: Overwinter stubbles were associated with increased grey partridge productivity.
[Statement 4]: When combined with other measures, overwinter stubbles were associated with an increased cirl bunting population size and territory density.
[Statement 5]: Several studies reported inconsistent or species-specific responses of birds to overwinter stubbles.
[Statement 6]: One study found a negative relationship between stubble area and grey partridge brood size.
[Statement 7]: Bird use of overwinter stubbles varied with stubble height and management.
[Statement 8]: In one randomized, controlled study, 22 of 23 species did not prefer stubbles over cover crops.
[Statement 9]: Replicated and controlled studies reported more bird species on spring-sown cereals than on winter cereals.
[Statement 10]: Bird population increases were reported after the start of spring sowing or on sites with spring-sown cereals.
[Statement 11]: One before-and-after study reported no species decreases in relation to spring sowing.
[Statement 12]: The benefits of spring sowing for birds were reduced where more autumn-sown crops surrounded sites.
[Statement 13]: One replicated, controlled study found lower hatching success for birds on spring-sown crops than on autumn-sown crops.

key: _gpt-5__For the benefit of farmland birds, what is the comparative evidence for sowing crops in spring versus leaving stubbles overwinter?
_gpt-5__What is the evidence base for the effectiveness of providing artificial nest sites, such as boxes for birds and bees, on European farmland?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: For solitary bees, 30 replicated trials across multiple regions, including Europe, found that nest boxes were occupied in 29 of the trials.
[Statement 2]: Many species of solitary bees used the nest boxes provided in the trials.
[Statement 3]: A study on farmland in Germany recorded endangered species nesting in artificial nest sites.
[Statement 4]: German experiments estimated the foraging ranges of solitary bees to be between 150 and 600 meters.
[Statement 5]: The German experiments indicated that nest boxes for solitary bees must be within 150 to 600 meters of foraging resources.
[Statement 6]: On agricultural land, three trials in India, Germany, and the USA showed that the number of occupied solitary bee nests could double over three years.
[Statement 7]: Parasitism and mortality in solitary bee nest boxes were documented across 11 trials with variable rates.
[Statement 8]: There is no direct evidence on the effects of introducing pre-stocked solitary-bee nest boxes on farmland wildlife.
[Statement 9]: For birds in European agricultural habitats, studies from Finland, the Netherlands, Sweden, Switzerland and the UK reported occupancy of nest boxes by multiple species.
[Statement 10]: Bird species reported to occupy nest boxes in European agricultural habitats include kestrel, long-eared owl, starling, tits, tree sparrow, stock dove, jackdaw, wryneck and hoopoe.
[Statement 11]: The provision of nest boxes led to increases in Eurasian kestrel clutches and breeding tree sparrows.
[Statement 12]: The success of bird nest boxes was related to habitat, with more success in areas with more pasture.
[Statement 13]: The success of bird nest boxes was related to the height of the box, with higher boxes having higher occupancy, more eggs, and more hatched young.
[Statement 14]: For European rollers in Spain, the use of nest boxes increased over time.
[Statement 15]: The use of nest boxes by European rollers in Spain varied by habitat.
[Statement 16]: The breeding success of European rollers did not differ between new and old nest boxes.
[Statement 17]: European rollers using older nest boxes laid their eggs earlier than those in new boxes.
[Statement 18]: For falcons, studies from Europe and elsewhere reported that local populations increased after nest-site installation in some cases.
[Statement 19]: High or equal-to-natural productivity for falcons was often recorded in artificial nest sites.
[Statement 20]: Other studies on falcons found lower productivity or non-use of artificial nest sites.
[Statement 21]: The use and productivity of falcon nest sites could vary with the design and position of the box.
[Statement 22]: For owls, UK and European studies reported apparent local population increases following the installation of artificial nests.
[Statement 23]: In several cases, high or equal-to-natural breeding success was reported for owls in artificial nests.
[Statement 24]: Other controlled studies on owls found lower productivity in artificial nests.
[Statement 25]: In some studies, species interactions affected the success of owls using artificial nests.
[Statement 26]: Some studies found lower juvenile survival for owls that came from artificial nests.
[Statement 27]: In some studies, the use of artificial nests by owls was at least as frequent as their use of natural sites.
[Statement 28]: In other studies, the use of artificial nests by owls varied with the nest's design and position.

[Statement 1]: In studies of restoring species-rich grassland, positive signs of restoration have been reported in under five years.
[Statement 2]: Some studies of restoring species-rich grassland reported positive signs of restoration within 10 years.
[Statement 3]: A few studies of restoring species-rich grassland found positive signs of restoration took more than 10 years.
[Statement 4]: Differences between restored and existing species-rich grasslands were detected nine years after restoration.
[Statement 5]: In some cases, differences between restored and existing species-rich grasslands were detected 60 years after restoration.
[Statement 6]: In grasslands restored from arable or bare soil, butterfly communities became increasingly similar to high-quality grasslands over the first 10 years.
[Statement 7]: Species richness was higher on grasslands created less than 10 years ago than on grasslands created more than 20 years ago.
[Statement 8]: In some cases, the number of butterfly species on seeded grassland remained similar each year over a 10-year period.
[Statement 9]: Some studies found that moth abundance did not increase with time since restoration.
[Statement 10]: For created or restored prairies, the abundance of Fender’s blue eggs was greater 5 to 10 years after restoration than at 1 to 2 years after restoration.
[Statement 11]: The abundance of Fender’s blue eggs on restored prairies was similar to the abundance on remnant prairies.
[Statement 12]: Following tree and shrub removal on wet meadows, marsh fritillary caterpillar webs increased the next year.

key: _gpt-5__When undertaking habitat restoration on farmland, such as creating species-rich grassland, what is the typical timeframe for seeing positive ecological changes?
_gpt-5__What are the overall effects of broad-scale agri-environment schemes on farmland biodiversity in Europe?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Across Europe, studies report mixed but often positive effects of agri-environment schemes on farmland biodiversity.
[Statement 2]: For birds, most studies found increases in population size, density or more favourable trends on sites with agri-environment schemes.
[Statement 3]: Some studies found that agri-environment schemes had negative or no effects on birds.
[Statement 4]: The outcomes of agri-environment schemes for birds could vary with management tier or placement.
[Statement 5]: For plants, several studies found agri-environment schemes maintained or had little to no effect on richness or diversity.
[Statement 6]: Some studies found agri-environment schemes increased plant richness or diversity, while other studies found decreases.
[Statement 7]: In England, Environmentally Sensitive Areas helped halt the loss of semi-natural grasslands but were less effective at enhancing or restoring biodiversity.
[Statement 8]: Flower abundance increased in some Estonian areas with agri-environment schemes.
[Statement 9]: For invertebrates, the results of agri-environment schemes were mixed, with some studies finding maintenance or little effect and others finding increases.
[Statement 10]: A UK study found that bee responses to agri-environment schemes were local rather than landscape-scale.
[Statement 11]: Bee-focused trials across Europe have shown both enhanced diversity and abundance under agri-environment schemes, as well as cases with no enhancement.
[Statement 12]: Two landscape-scale trials in the UK found no enhancement of bumblebee populations from agri-environment schemes.
[Statement 13]: For mammals, UK evidence showed one positive study and three with mixed effects depending on the region or species.
[Statement 14]: For bats, UK studies reported no significant differences between farms with agri-environment schemes and conventional farms in most cases.
[Statement 15]: Some UK studies on bats found instances of lower activity on farms with agri-environment schemes.
[Statement 16]: For amphibians, European evidence includes the creation of breeding habitat or increased frog and toad populations in Denmark and Sweden.
[Statement 17]: In the Netherlands, amphibian species numbers and abundance were higher in ditches under agri-environment schemes than in conventionally managed ditches.
[Statement 18]: Baseline comparisons in certain studies noted that some wildlife numbers were higher before the implementation of agri-environment schemes.
[Statement 19]: Two baseline datasets found no overall differences in birds or soil biota between areas with and without agri-environment schemes.

[Statement 1]: A replicated controlled trial on heather moorland in Northern Ireland reported that plots managed by flailing (swiping) to simulate burning had more plant species eight years after treatment than untreated controls.
[Statement 2]: A replicated controlled trial on heather moorland in Northern Ireland reported that plots managed by flailing (swiping) to simulate burning had fewer species than burned plots.
[Statement 3]: A replicated controlled trial in Northern Ireland reported that a single burn on heather moorland increased plant species numbers eight years after treatment compared to unburned control plots.

key: _gpt-5__For managing heather moorland in the UK, what is the comparative evidence for the effectiveness of swiping versus controlled burning on plant diversity?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Across 17 studies from Austria, Belgium, Germany, Ireland, Switzerland and the UK, using organic rather than mineral fertilizers was reported to support higher plant diversity, cover and/or species richness.
[Statement 2]: The use of organic fertilizers instead of mineral fertilizers was reported to increase earthworm abundance, diversity, biomass, and/or density.
[Statement 3]: Using organic fertilizers was reported to increase the abundance and/or species richness of some or all investigated invertebrate groups.
[Statement 4]: One review noted that organic fertilizers without pesticides produced the highest earthworm biomass.
[Statement 5]: A small Belgian trial found more predatory beetles two years after organic fertilizer application compared to a control.
[Statement 6]: One randomized, replicated, controlled UK trial found no effect on the abundance of three weed species from using organic fertilizers.
[Statement 7]: A replicated Irish study found no long-term effect of farmyard manure on invertebrates.
[Statement 8]: Two UK studies reported that increases in arthropod predators and springtails were local rather than field-scale.
[Statement 9]: One review reported a UK study where heavy slurry applications were toxic to common earthworms.
[Statement 10]: Soils with organic fertilizer had more microbial biomass in some comparisons.
[Statement 11]: Individual studies reported that soils with organic fertilizer had fewer bacteria, fewer nematodes, or fewer mites than with inorganic fertilizer.
[Statement 12]: Some studies found inconsistent differences in microbial communities between soils with organic and inorganic fertilizers.

key: _gpt-5__What are the documented effects on farmland biodiversity of switching from mineral to organic fertilizers?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Undersowing spring cereals can increase barnacle goose abundance.
[Statement 2]: Undersowing spring cereals can increase the densities of singing Eurasian skylark and nesting dunnock.
[Statement 3]: Undersowing spring cereals can increase the abundances or species richness of arthropods, bumblebees, butterflies, earthworms, ground beetles, spiders and springtails.
[Statement 4]: In a UK study, spring barley undersown with grasses and legumes had higher butterfly species richness and abundance than extensively or conventionally managed grassland.
[Statement 5]: In a UK study, caterpillar abundance was lower on fields of spring barley undersown with grasses and legumes.
[Statement 6]: A Swiss study found similar butterfly richness and abundance on farms with more in-field options, including undersown cereals, compared to farms with fewer in-field options.
[Statement 7]: Some studies found no benefits from undersowing for some invertebrates, plants, or grey partridge indicators.
[Statement 8]: Some studies found no benefits for the nesting densities of two of three farmland bird species.
[Statement 9]: One UK study found only one of five bird species was more frequent on undersown wheat stubbles than on conventionally managed barley.
[Statement 10]: UK studies reported that not all species nested at higher densities on undersown fields.
[Statement 11]: UK studies reported that grey partridge population health declined as the area of undersown fields increased.
[Statement 12]: UK studies reported there was no relationship between the amount of undersown cereals and grey partridge productivity.

key: _gpt-5__As an alternative to conventional ploughing, what are the wildlife benefits of undersowing spring cereals?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The creation of uncropped, cultivated margins or plots has been reported to increase the species richness of plants and bumblebees.
[Statement 2]: Uncropped, cultivated margins or plots can lead to higher species richness and/or abundance of spiders.
[Statement 3]: The abundance of ground-dwelling invertebrates and ground beetles is reportedly higher in areas with uncropped, cultivated margins or plots.
[Statement 4]: The creation of uncropped, cultivated margins or plots has been linked to an increased stone curlew breeding population size.
[Statement 5]: Northern lapwing hatching success is higher in areas with uncropped, cultivated margins or plots.
[Statement 6]: Eurasian skylark nesting success is higher in areas with uncropped, cultivated margins or plots.
[Statement 7]: Uncropped, cultivated margins or plots can support the establishment, abundance, or species richness of rare arable plants.
[Statement 8]: Lapwing, skylark, grey partridge, and yellow wagtail have been observed breeding on lapwing plots.
[Statement 9]: Schemes promoting uncropped, cultivated plots have led to increased numbers of Eurasian thick-knee.
[Statement 10]: Multiple species have been observed using lapwing plots for foraging or nesting.
[Statement 11]: Some studies found higher nesting success in fallow fields or lapwing plots than in crops.
[Statement 12]: Some studies found a higher abundance of butterflies and micro-moths on farms with agri-environment schemes that include uncropped, cultivated margins.
[Statement 13]: In one of two years studied, fields with wider uncropped margins showed higher butterfly abundance and richness.
[Statement 14]: A higher abundance of some butterfly species was found under enhanced agri-environment options, though other butterflies were lower in abundance.
[Statement 15]: Some studies found that uncropped, cultivated margins or plots had no effect on 11 out of 12 farmland bird species.
[Statement 16]: In some studies, uncropped, cultivated margins or plots had no effect on ground beetles.
[Statement 17]: In two of three regions studied, there were fewer seed-eating birds on fallow plots.
[Statement 18]: Uncropped cultivated margins were found to have more pernicious weeds than conservation or conventional headlands.
[Statement 19]: A lower proportion of young grey partridges was observed where uncropped, cultivated margins or plots were common.
[Statement 20]: Uncropped, cultivated plots were found to have no effect on changes in grey partridge density.
[Statement 21]: Eleven bird species were not associated with uncropped, cultivated plots.
[Statement 22]: In two of three regions studied, fewer birds used uncropped, cultivated plots than cropland.
[Statement 23]: The productivity of grey partridges was not related to the amount of lapwing plots.
[Statement 24]: A lower proportion of young partridges was found on sites with many cultivated fallow plots.
[Statement 25]: Several studies reported that the species richness or abundance of butterflies and moths was similar on farms or fields with uncropped, cultivated margins compared to control areas.

key: _gpt-5__What are the observed benefits and drawbacks of creating uncropped, cultivated margins or plots on UK farmland?
_gpt-5__What factors influence the occupancy and success rates of nest boxes provided for birds on farmland?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Nest box design can alter the use, productivity, and usurpation of the nest box.
[Statement 2]: Some studies found that nest box design had no effect.
[Statement 3]: The design and positioning of nest boxes affected occupancy in wildfowl.
[Statement 4]: Some nest box designs also reduced use by competitor species.
[Statement 5]: Various studies found different occupation or success rates for nest boxes depending on the box's position or orientation.
[Statement 6]: Hidden nest boxes had higher success rates.
[Statement 7]: For wildfowl, nest boxes placed over water were more successful than nest boxes placed in trees over land.
[Statement 8]: Nest boxes positioned higher above the ground had higher occupancy, more eggs, and more hatched young.
[Statement 9]: The success of nests within boxes was related to the amount of available pasture.
[Statement 10]: Tree sparrows' preference for wetland nest boxes over farmland nest boxes affected occupancy.
[Statement 11]: More nesting attempts occurred in areas where more nest boxes were available.
[Statement 12]: Nest box occupancy rates varied widely across different sites.
[Statement 13]: Nest box occupancy rates sometimes increased over time.
[Statement 14]: Some target bird groups showed low use of provided nest boxes.
[Statement 15]: Many other bird species used provided nest boxes.
[Statement 16]: Certain species did not use the provided nest structures in farmland.

[Statement 1]: A replicated controlled trial in Northern Ireland found that eight years after management, heather moorland plots treated by swiping (flailing) had more plant species than unflailed control plots.
[Statement 2]: A replicated controlled trial in Northern Ireland found that eight years after management, heather moorland plots treated by swiping (flailing) had fewer plant species than burned plots.
[Statement 3]: Plots subject to a single burn had more plant species eight years after management than unburned control plots.

key: _gpt-5__On UK moorland, what are the comparative effects on plant species richness of managing heather by swiping versus controlled burning?
_gpt-5__What is the typical timeframe to see positive changes in plant communities when restoring species-rich or wet grasslands from intensive agriculture?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Across multiple European studies on restoring species-rich grassland, six studies observed positive signs of restoration in under five years.
[Statement 2]: In studies on restoring species-rich grassland in Europe, 11 studies observed positive signs of restoration within 10 years.
[Statement 3]: Two European studies on restoring species-rich grassland reported restoration taking more than 10 years.
[Statement 4]: Several European studies on restoring species-rich grassland recorded limited or slow plant community change after restoration.
[Statement 5]: For wet meadows, 13 studies monitoring relatively shortly after restoration reported some positive plant community effects within five years.
[Statement 6]: Three studies on wet meadows found restoration was not complete five, nine or 20 years after intervention.
[Statement 7]: One study on wet meadows found plant species richness increased with time since restoration.

key: _gpt-5__What are the documented benefits and drawbacks of reducing tillage intensity on European farmland?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Reducing tillage compared to conventional management was associated with increased biomass, species richness or abundance of earthworms.
[Statement 2]: Reducing tillage was associated with a greater abundance of some non-earthworm invertebrates.
[Statement 3]: Reducing tillage was associated with increased numbers of some weeds and/or weed species.
[Statement 4]: Reduced tillage was associated with higher Eurasian skylark nest density, earlier laying dates, and shorter foraging distances.
[Statement 5]: A greater abundance of some birds, including Eurasian skylarks, seed-eating songbirds and gamebirds, was observed in late winter on non-inversion or conservation tillage fields.
[Statement 6]: A review reported that tillage had negative effects on invertebrate numbers.
[Statement 7]: A review reported that no-till systems had more invertebrate bird food resources.
[Statement 8]: Other studies found negative, no, or inconsistent effects of reduced tillage on some invertebrates, including earthworms.
[Statement 9]: Some studies found negative, no, or inconsistent effects of reduced tillage on seed bank richness and the numbers of some weed species.
[Statement 10]: Other studies found negative, no, or inconsistent effects of reduced tillage on mammals and some bird species.
[Statement 11]: One study found bird preferences for conservation tillage fields decreased over time.
[Statement 12]: Crop type influenced weed numbers under different tillage regimes.
[Statement 13]: There is no evidence assessing the effects of reduced tillage on amphibians.
[Statement 14]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of managing tillage practices on reptiles.
[Statement 15]: In some European comparisons, soils under no-till had more organic matter, nitrogen, or phosphorus than soils under reduced tillage.
[Statement 16]: In other European comparisons, soils under no-till had similar amounts of organic matter, nitrogen, or phosphorus as soils under reduced tillage.
[Statement 17]: Soils under no-till and reduced tillage had similar potassium levels.
[Statement 18]: Microbial biomass was mostly similar between no-till and reduced tillage systems.
[Statement 19]: Soils under no-till systems had fewer denitrifying bacteria.
[Statement 20]: One study found more mites in soils under no-till systems.
[Statement 21]: In some comparisons, soil aggregates were larger under no-till systems, while in others the aggregates were a similar size to those in reduced tillage systems.
[Statement 22]: A comparison between no-till and reduced tillage systems showed mixed results for water-stability.
[Statement 23]: Greenhouse gas emissions were sometimes lower or similar under no-till systems relative to reduced tillage systems.

[Statement 1]: Planting wild bird seed or cover mixtures was associated with higher bird abundance, density, species diversity, and richness on fields compared to other farmland habitats in multiple UK studies.
[Statement 2]: Birds showed a preference for and greater use of cover areas planted with wild bird seed or cover mixtures.
[Statement 3]: Some wild bird seed or cover mixtures that include kale attracted the most species or the highest abundance of birds.
[Statement 4]: Providing supplementary food increased farmland bird abundance, breeding population size, density, body mass, hatching, nestling growth, and fledging rates in several studies.
[Statement 5]: Providing supplementary food increased overwinter survival in a declining house sparrow population.
[Statement 6]: Other studies reported that providing supplementary food had no clear effects on breeding abundance, survival in stable house sparrow populations, or other metrics.
[Statement 7]: One study found lower fledging rates in one year when supplementary food was provided.
[Statement 8]: The use of supplementary food by birds varied by species, season, and proximity to other food sources.

key: _gpt-5__What is the comparative effectiveness of providing supplementary food versus planting wild bird seed mixtures for supporting farmland birds over winter?
_gpt-5__What is the extent of the evidence for the effectiveness of managing or planting new hedgerows to benefit wildlife on farmland?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Ten studies from Switzerland and the UK reported that managing hedgerows for wildlife resulted in increases in berry yields.
[Statement 2]: Ten studies from Switzerland and the UK reported that managing hedgerows for wildlife resulted in increases in plant and invertebrate diversity or richness.
[Statement 3]: Ten studies from Switzerland and the UK reported that managing hedgerows for wildlife resulted in increases in farmland bird diversity or abundance.
[Statement 4]: Five UK studies found that managing hedgerows had no effects on plant richness, bumblebee queen numbers, or farmland birds.
[Statement 5]: Two replicated studies reported that managing hedgerows had mixed or adverse effects, including a reduced hawthorn berry yield.
[Statement 6]: A replicated site comparison found that hedges cut every two years provided more suitable nesting habitat for grey partridge.
[Statement 7]: Removing fruit-bearing wood from hedgerows was found to reduce hawthorn berry yield.
[Statement 8]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of managing hedgerows on farmland mammals.
[Statement 9]: Seventeen studies showed that more structurally complex or tree-containing hedgerows were associated with higher species richness and diversity of butterflies and moths.
[Statement 10]: Certain cutting regimes for hedgerows were associated with higher species richness and diversity of butterflies and moths.
[Statement 11]: In multiple cases, specific hedgerow structures and cutting regimes were associated with a higher abundance of butterflies, moths, caterpillars, pupae, and brown hairstreak eggs.
[Statement 12]: Several studies found similar richness or abundance of butterflies and moths under both agri-environment and conventional hedgerow management.
[Statement 13]: Some studies reported lower caterpillar abundance in managed hedgerows compared to remnant hedgerows.
[Statement 14]: Seven studies found that established hedgerows often had higher species richness and abundance of butterflies and moths than beetle banks, crops, pasture, grass margins, or field interiors.
[Statement 15]: One study reported that the species richness of butterflies and moths in established hedgerows was similar to that on grass banks.
[Statement 16]: One behavior study showed that moths tended to fly parallel to hedgerows.
[Statement 17]: Two UK studies on hedgerow management found more bat species and higher activity for some species along hedges trimmed three or more years prior compared to those trimmed the previous winter.
[Statement 18]: Pipistrelle bat activity did not differ between hedges managed for wildlife on agri-environment scheme farms and those on conventional farms.
[Statement 19]: No studies were found on the effects of planting new hedges for bats.
[Statement 20]: Three studies reported that retaining or enhancing hedgerows with other boundary features was associated with higher brown hare density in arable sites.
[Statement 21]: Retaining or enhancing hedgerows with other boundary features was not associated with higher brown hare density in grassland sites.
[Statement 22]: The number of Irish hares did not increase with the retention or enhancement of hedgerows.
[Statement 23]: Establishing hedgerows alongside arable land increased the abundance of small mammals.

key: _gpt-5__How do farm-level agri-environment scheme options scale up to benefit biodiversity at the landscape level?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Many studies across Europe report higher densities, population sizes, or more favorable trends of some birds on agri-environment scheme (AES) sites than on non-AES sites.
[Statement 2]: Other studies found mixed or no effects of agri-environment schemes on bird populations.
[Statement 3]: Higher-tier management within agri-environment schemes sometimes resulted in higher bird numbers.
[Statement 4]: The siting of agri-environment scheme agreements influenced the schemes' effectiveness.
[Statement 5]: One UK study reported that agri-environment scheme prescriptions had local but not landscape-scale effects on bee numbers.
[Statement 6]: Two UK landscape-scale trials found that bumblebee populations were not enhanced on farmland with agri-environment schemes compared to farmland without the schemes.
[Statement 7]: Farms managed under agri-environment schemes sometimes had a higher abundance of butterflies and micro-moths than conventionally managed farms.
[Statement 8]: Agri-environment scheme options include uncropped cultivated margins and wild bird seed plots.
[Statement 9]: Comparisons of farms with larger versus smaller areas of in-field agri-environment scheme options often showed similar butterfly richness or abundance.
[Statement 10]: Wider field margins increased butterfly richness or abundance in some years.
[Statement 11]: Replicated paired-site studies in the UK found that overall bat activity or occurrence often did not differ between agri-environment scheme farms and conventional farms.
[Statement 12]: In some cases, bat activity or occurrence was lower on agri-environment scheme farms.
[Statement 13]: Hedges trimmed three or more years prior had more bat species recorded and higher activity for some species than hedges trimmed the previous winter.
[Statement 14]: In wetland-focused options, raising water levels in ditches or grassland was associated with increased bird numbers, including breeding birds.
[Statement 15]: Raising water levels in ditches or grassland was associated with an increase in plant species that favor wet conditions.
[Statement 16]: Raising water levels in ditches or grassland was associated with increased invertebrate numbers or biomass.
[Statement 17]: A UK review indicated that more expensive options like water-level control were more effective for providing habitat for wading birds than easier options.
[Statement 18]: Evidence indicates that while several farm-level agri-environment scheme options can produce local gains, landscape-scale responses vary by the type of animal or plant group.
[Statement 19]: Landscape-scale responses to agri-environment schemes vary by the extent or placement of the scheme's implementation.

key: _gpt-5__Following the restoration of grassland from other land uses on European farmland, what is the typical timeframe to see changes in plant communities?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Based on a review of 22 studies from seven European countries, six studies saw positive signs of grassland community restoration in less than five years.
[Statement 2]: Based on a review of 22 European studies, eleven studies saw positive signs of grassland community restoration within 10 years.
[Statement 3]: Based on a review of 22 European studies, two studies reported that grassland community restoration took more than 10 years.
[Statement 4]: Six studies reported limited or slow changes in plant communities following grassland restoration.
[Statement 5]: Two studies in Germany and the UK found differences in vegetation between restored and existing species-rich grasslands nine years after restoration.
[Statement 6]: Two studies in Germany and the UK found differences in vegetation between restored and existing species-rich grasslands 60 years after restoration.

[Statement 1]: Evidence on controlling mammal populations for UK farmland wildlife is mixed and taxon-specific.
[Statement 2]: There is no captured evidence on the effects of managing wild deer numbers on farmland wildlife.
[Statement 3]: There is no captured evidence on the effects of controlling grey squirrels on farmland wildlife.
[Statement 4]: A systematic review reported that trapping reduces American mink populations.
[Statement 5]: Firm conclusions from a systematic review on trapping American mink were limited by experimental design.
[Statement 6]: A large-scale UK trapping programme eradicated mink over a large area.
[Statement 7]: The eradication of mink in a large-scale UK trapping programme may have been associated with localized water vole expansions.
[Statement 8]: For broader predator control that includes mammalian predators alongside birds, UK and French studies reported increased abundance or population size of some birds.
[Statement 9]: For broader predator control that includes mammalian predators alongside birds, UK and French studies reported some evidence of increased productivity, nest or reproductive success or survival.
[Statement 10]: A global systematic review found the reproductive success of birds increased with predator removal.

key: _gpt-5__What is the extent of evidence for controlling mammal populations, such as deer, squirrels, and mink, to benefit farmland wildlife in the UK?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: In the UK, semi-natural grasslands restored by scrub clearance and the reintroduction of grazing or mowing had butterfly communities that differed from existing species-rich grasslands.
[Statement 2]: Butterfly communities on restored semi-natural grasslands did not become more similar over time to those on existing species-rich grasslands.
[Statement 3]: Butterfly species richness on restored UK grassland sites remained similar over time since restoration.
[Statement 4]: Several comparisons found higher species richness or abundance of butterflies and moths on less intensively managed grasslands than on conventionally managed sites.
[Statement 5]: A before-and-after study in the UK reported that after reducing grazing and stopping chemical applications, large moth species richness and total abundance increased.
[Statement 6]: In a UK study, reducing grazing and stopping chemical applications led to increases in five of 23 butterfly species and decreases in two species.
[Statement 7]: Broader multi-taxa evidence reported that reduced management intensity benefited invertebrates in many studies.
[Statement 8]: Some studies found that reduced management intensity had mixed or no effects on invertebrates.
[Statement 9]: Some studies found more invertebrates under intensive grassland management.
[Statement 10]: Invertebrate communities on less intensively managed grasslands were distinct from invertebrate communities on intensively managed grasslands.

key: _gpt-5__For improving invertebrate biodiversity in UK grasslands, what is the comparative evidence between reducing management intensity versus restoring species-rich semi-natural grassland?
_gpt-5__In the Netherlands, what are the most effective management strategies for increasing wading bird populations on wet grasslands?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Evidence from the Netherlands indicates that maintaining traditional water meadows can increase populations or territories of northern lapwing, common redshank and black‑tailed godwit.
[Statement 2]: The impacts of maintaining traditional water meadows on species other than northern lapwing, common redshank and black‑tailed godwit can vary.
[Statement 3]: A replicated site comparison found more birds bred on 12.5 hectare plots that combined wader‑focused management with per‑clutch payments.
[Statement 4]: In the same site comparison, field‑scale abundance and richness did not differ from conventional fields.
[Statement 5]: Raising water levels in ditches or grassland was associated with increased bird numbers in agricultural landscapes.
[Statement 6]: A randomized, controlled study in the Netherlands found that raising water-levels accelerated the establishment of vegetation typical of wet grassland.
[Statement 7]: One study in the Netherlands reported that raising water levels had no effect on the foraging rate of lapwings.
[Statement 8]: Some studies found that raising water levels led to net plant species losses.
[Statement 9]: In studies that included the Netherlands, delaying mowing or first grazing dates increased the densities of breeding wading birds.
[Statement 10]: Delaying mowing or first grazing dates also provided benefits to other taxa.
[Statement 11]: Direct per‑clutch payments on Dutch farms showed limited evidence for increasing wading bird populations.
[Statement 12]: Direct per‑clutch payments were associated with higher hatching success for lapwing and black‑tailed godwit.
[Statement 13]: When combined with postponed agricultural activities, per-clutch payments resulted in more birds breeding on 12.5 hectare plots compared to control plots.
[Statement 14]: The restoration or creation of traditional water meadows has had reported successes in multiple European countries, including the Netherlands.
[Statement 15]: Techniques used for restoring or creating traditional water meadows include raising water levels, grazing, mowing, topsoil removal and species introductions.
[Statement 16]: Some studies on water meadow restoration noted reduced or limited success and incomplete restoration even after several years.

[Statement 1]: Uncropped plots in arable fields can increase plant species richness and lead to the establishment of rare arable plants.
[Statement 2]: Uncropped plots can result in a higher abundance or richness of bumblebees, spiders, ground-dwelling invertebrates, and ground beetles.
[Statement 3]: Positive responses in some farmland birds to uncropped plots include an increased stone-curlew breeding population size.
[Statement 4]: The creation of uncropped plots can lead to higher northern lapwing hatching success.
[Statement 5]: Uncropped plots can improve Eurasian skylark nesting success.
[Statement 6]: Lapwing, skylark, grey partridge, and yellow wagtail use lapwing plots for breeding.
[Statement 7]: Farms or fields with uncropped cultivated margins or plots sometimes had a higher abundance of butterflies and micro-moths.
[Statement 8]: The abundance of some butterfly species was sometimes higher in fields with uncropped plots, though overall species richness and abundance were often similar to conventional farms.
[Statement 9]: Butterfly and moth species richness and abundance in fields with uncropped plots varied among species and years.
[Statement 10]: Skylark plots, which are undrilled patches, showed positive effects on the skylark population size, breeding density, and breeding duration or success.
[Statement 11]: Additional benefits of skylark plots for plants and some invertebrates were reported.
[Statement 12]: A documented limitation is that some studies found uncropped plots had no effect on many bird species or on ground beetles.
[Statement 13]: In two of three regions studied, there were fewer seed-eating birds on fallow plots created for ground-nesting birds.
[Statement 14]: Uncropped cultivated margins had a greater occurrence of pernicious weeds than conservation or conventional headlands.
[Statement 15]: A lower proportion of young grey partridges was found in populations where uncropped cultivated margins or plots were common.
[Statement 16]: For butterflies and moths, several studies found that species richness or abundance was similar in fields with uncropped plots and fields under conventional management.
[Statement 17]: The abundance responses of butterflies and moths to uncropped plots varied among different species.
[Statement 18]: Some studies found no significant differences for some invertebrates or seed-eating songbirds in skylark plots when compared to conventional fields.

key: _gpt-5__What are the documented benefits and limitations of creating uncropped plots in arable fields for wildlife?
